HST110.name: Historical Approaches to Contemporary Issues
HST110.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST110.description: Origins, contexts, and meaning of a current issue. Use of historical methods to understand an important problem or issue.

HST140.name: World History to 1500
HST140.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST140.description: Similarities and distinctive qualities of civilizations in the pre-modern era. Social, cultural, and economic influences and interactions.

HST150.name: World History since 1500
HST150.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST150.description: The making of the modern world with focus on international relations. Major changes in culture and human understanding of the world.

HST160.name: Introduction to Asian History and Culture
HST160.description: History and culture of East, South and Southeast Asia in the early modern and modern periods.

HST201.name: Historical Methods and Skills
HST201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST201.description: The nature and discipline of history. Introduction to analytical and interpretive reading and writing, historical research, and historical methodologies.

HST201H.name: Historical Methods and Skills for Honors Students
HST201H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST201H.description: The nature and discipline of history. Introduction to analytical and interpretive reading and writing, historical research, and historical methodologies.
HST201H.restrictions: Open to students in the Honors College.

HST202.name: U.S. History to 1876
HST202.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST202.description: Major topics and themes in U.S. history from the colonial and revolutionary periods through the Civil War and reconstruction.

HST203.name: U.S. History since 1876
HST203.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST203.description: Major topics and themes in U.S. history from 1876 to the present including such topics as political development, social change, women's history, race and ethnicity.

HST205.name: The Ancient Mediterranean and the Medieval World
HST205.description: Major political, cultural, social and economic developments and themes from the ancient civilizations to the late Middle Ages. Mesopotamia and Egypt. Greece and Rome. Charlemagne and the Franks. Normans and Crusaders. Popes and feudal monarchs. Bubonic plagues. The early Renaissance.

HST206.name: European History since 1500
HST206.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST206.description: Major topics in European history from 1500 to present including Reformation, Renaissance, Enlightenment, the French Revolution, social, political changes in nineteenth century, nature of twentieth century.

HST208.name: Introduction to African History, Culture and Society
HST208.description: General survey of the history, culture and society of Africa, from around 1500 to the present. Interplay between internal and external socio-economic, political, cultural and religious forces in African societies.

HST209.name: Traditional East Asia
HST209.description: Major trends in the history, government, religion, philosophy, society and cultures of China, Japan and Korea.

HST210.name: Modern East Asia
HST210.description: Major trends in the history, government, religion, philosophy, society and cultures of China, Japan and Korea. Evolving East-West contacts.

HST211.name: Colonial Latin America
HST211.description: Political, economic and social structures in the Spanish and Portuguese empires. Emergence of multi-racial, multi-cultural societies through the interaction of Amerindians, Europeans and Africans.

HST212.name: National Latin America
HST212.description: Political, economic and social history of Latin America from the 1820s to the present, including relations between Latin America and the United States.

HST213.name: U.S. Business and Economic History
HST213.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST213.description: Evolution of American economy from colonial period to the present. Relationship between government and business. The relationship of labor to industry and government. Political culture and the world of business.

HST220.name: History of Food and Alcohol
HST220.description: How food and alcohol have shaped world history. Relationship to politics, nationalism, religion, economics and culture. Consumption, trade, migration, slavery, globalization, environmental impacts.

HST225.name: Law, History and Society in the United States
HST225.description: Legal history of the United States. How law shapes and is shaped by culture and society. Framing the Constitution. Religious freedom. Gender and the law. Race and the law.

HST250.name: History and Technology of the Digital Age
HST250.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST250.description: Historical foundations of modern computing technology.

HST251.name: Doing Digital History
HST251.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST251.description: Historical data mining. New technologies for historical data analysis. Web-based presentations of historical material.

HST255.name: American Cinema and the American Century
HST255.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
HST255.description: History, evolution and transformation of the film industry in the extended twentieth century. From penny arcades and nickelodeons to the leading section of the global entertainment industry. Social and economic circumstances shaping developments in the film industry. Representations of race, gender and class in motion pictures. Production, distribution, consumption and reception of motion pictures in specific historical periods.

HST260.name: Navigations and Encounters in an Age of Discovery
HST260.description: European voyages and navigations, 1400-1600. Developments in cartography and technology. Cultural encounters with non-European peoples.

HST281.name: Atlantic Slavery
HST281.description: Slavery and human trafficking in western Europe, Africa and the Americas from the fifteenth century to the present.

HST293.name: Witches, Demons and the Occult in Pre-Modern Europe
HST293.description: Witch hunts in Europe in their religious and social contexts. European beliefs about magic, demonology and the occult from the late Middle Ages to c. 1700.

HST294.name: History of Catholicism, Late Antiquity to the Present
HST294.description: Roman Catholicism. Changing structures of administration, instruments of repression, and responses to and impact on social, cultural and political transformations. Missionary movements, orders and councils.

HST295.name: The Nazis
HST295.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST295.description: Genesis of National Socialism and its trajectory as a political movement and dictatorship. Life in the Third Reich. Regime's military and genocidal aims. Role of Adolf Hitler.

HST301.name: Indigenous-European Encounters in North America
HST301.description: European-Indigenous encounters and long-term perspectives on Indigenous and European contact

HST302.name: Revolutionary America
HST302.description: The American Revolutionary era in an international context, 1763-1826. Liberty and equality in a world of empires, republics and slavery. Role of gender, race and class in defining the meaning of the revolution. The U.S. Constitution. Early American diplomacy in transition from colony to nation.

HST303.name: The Young American Republic
HST303.description: Rise of political democracy in the United States, 1820-1850. Emergence of a market economy and industrialization. Movements by laborers, women, African Americans, immigrants and Native Americans to expand rights. Religious and cultural change. Sectional conflict between North and South. Westward expansion, Oregon Trail, Gold Rush.

HST304.name: The Civil War Era
HST304.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST304.description: Political, constitutional, social, economic and military conflict between the North and the South, 1848-1876. Political realignment and birth of the Republican Party. States rights and secession. U.S. and C.S.A governments at war. Military campaigns, strategies, leadership. Slavery, emancipation, equal rights. Reconstruction.

HST305.name: The Making of the Modern United States
HST305.description: Social, economic, and political transformations, 1877-1929. Rise of the modern United States. Gilded Age, robber barons, high finance. Industrialization. Science, technology and innovation. Populism, Jim Crow, woman suffrage, labor unrest, immigration, ethnicity. Imperialism. Progressive reform. Popular culture, amusements, media.

HST306.name: Modern United States
HST306.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST306.description: United States history from 1920 to the present. Transformations in political, economic, and social institutions and Americans' responses to these changes. Development of the welfare-warfare state. The transformation to a post-industrial economy. Political and cultural responses to these changes.

HST309.name: American Indian History: Precontact to the Present
HST309.description: Gendered overview of indigenous history in the Americas. Precontact, encounter, intrusion and resistance to settler colonialism, forced removal, reservations, boarding schools, allotment, indigenous sovereignty.

HST310.name: African American History to 1876
HST310.description: American slavery in the mainland colonies. Establishment and nature of free black communities. The impact of emancipation.

HST311.name: African American History since 1876
HST311.description: Blacks in America from Reconstruction to the present. Grass roots and cultural revitalization. The Civil Rights movement and black power.

HST312.name: African American Women
HST312.description: Black women in American history. Slavery, the work place, politics, and the Civil Rights movement.

HST313.name: Women in the United States to 1869
HST313.description: United States history through the experiences of women. Gender, family, work, and political activism.

HST314.name: Women in the United States since 1869
HST314.description: United States history through the experiences of women. Gender, family, work, and political activism.

HST315.name: American Intellectual History to 1860
HST315.description: Development and influence of major ideas from the colonial period to 1860. Topics include Puritanism, the Enlightenment, Romanticism, and the women's movement.

HST316.name: United States Intellectual History since 1860
HST316.description: Development and influence of major ideas from 1860 to present. Topics include Social Darwinism, imperialism, religion, and women's rights.

HST317.name: American Jewish History
HST317.description: American Jewish history from colonial period to present. Jewish immigration to the United States, patterns of religious and cultural adjustment, social relations and anti-Semitism, Jewish politics, the construction of Jewish identities.

HST318A.name: United States Constitutional History to 1890
HST318A.description: Formation of the Union. Articles of Confederation. Origins, formation, and development of the Constitution. Role of the Supreme Court. Landmark cases. Law and society. Economic issues. Slavery and emancipation.
HST318A.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HST318B.name: United States Constitutional History from 1877
HST318B.description: Social, economic, political and legal developments affecting the interpretation of the Constitution from the end of Reconstruction to the present. Role of the Supreme Court. Landmark cases.
HST318B.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HST319.name: Asian American History
HST319.description: Survey of Asian American history from mid-nineteenth century to present. Analysis of shared and different experiences of the Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino, Vietnamese, Hmong, and East Indian peoples who have come to the United States.
HST319.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HST320.name: History of Michigan
HST320.description: Political, social, and economic development from colonial beginnings to the present.

HST321.name: History of the American West
HST321.description: Westward movement of people from European and African origins into Native American lands. Contact and conflict among cultures. Role of the west in national economic and political development.

HST322.name: History of the American South
HST322.description: Development of southern society, with emphasis on relationships among the races. Role of the south in economic, social, and political development of the nation.

HST324.name: History of Sport in America
HST324.description: Social and cultural ramifications of colonial sport. Rise of modern sport in the nineteenth century. Social significance of sport in modern America with special attention to economics, gender, race, and politics.

HST325.name: United States Foreign Relations to 1914
HST325.description: Foreign policy of the United States from Benjamin Franklin and the origins of the nation to 1914. Topics include Jeffersonian foreign policy, the War of 1812, the Monroe Doctrine, and the rise to world power.

HST326.name: United States Foreign Relations since 1914
HST326.description: Foreign policy of the United States from the outbreak of World War I to the present. Topics include Wilson's foreign policy, the policy of isolation, World War II, the Cold War, the Vietnam War, and current developments.

HST327.name: History of Mexican Americans in the United States
HST327.description: Mexican American history from 1492 to present. Cultural, social, economic, and political activities of Mexican Americans. Relationship of Mexican Americans to other groups.

HST328.name: Military History of the United States 1900-Present
HST328.description: Military history of the United States in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. American involvement in major conflicts

HST329.name: College Sports in the United States
HST329.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
HST329.description: Origins of sports in higher education. Effects of industrialization and television. Civil rights movement in sports

HST330.name: Ancient Greek History to 200 BCE
HST330.description: Major social, cultural and political themes in the history of ancient Greece from the Bronze Age to Alexander the Great. Minoan and Mycenaean civilization, rise of the polis, Athenian democracy, Persian and Peloponnesian Wars, Alexander's empire. Consideration of art, architecture, literature, religion, women, and gender.

HST331.name: Ancient Roman History 200 BCE to 500 CE
HST331.description: Social, economic, and political history of Rome from its origins until the collapse of the Mediterranean empire.

HST332.name: Medieval Europe
HST332.description: Europe in the Middle Ages. End of the Western Roman Empire. Germanic kingdoms. Islam and the Mediterranean. The Christian church in the early Middle Ages. Carolingian empire and renaissance. The Vikings. Medieval learning. Chivalry. Formation of states. Feudal tenure. Economic revival and growth of towns. Hundred Years War. The Black Death. Popular Rebellion. Religion and Spirituality.

HST334A.name: Renaissance and Reformation Europe
HST334A.description: Western Europe from 1450 to 1575. Intellectual developments of the Renaissance. Religious trends of the Reformation and Counter-Reformation. Political and imperial history.

HST334B.name: Seventeenth-Century Europe
HST334B.description: European history from 1575 to 1715. Rise of modern states. Thirty Years' War. Absolutism and revolt. Growth of Empire. Scientific revolution.

HST335.name: Europe in the Age of Revolution, 1700-1870
HST335.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST335.description: European political, social, economic, and cultural developments from the Old Regime to German unification. Topics include the French Revolution, the Industrial Revolution and the Revolutions of 1848.

HST336.name: Europe from Bismarck to Brexit
HST336.description: Politics, society, economy, and culture of Europe and Europe's relations with the wider world, from 1870 to the present, focusing on histories of violence and conflict and struggles for community, including world wars, revolutions, colonialism, decolonization, and European integration.

HST338.name: European Power, Culture and Thought: The Modern Era
HST338.description: Ideas in historical context, 1750-1980. Enlightenment, revolution, conservatism, romanticism. Liberalism, socialism, Marx. Science, realism; anti-positivism, Nietzsche, Freud. Modernism in art and social theory. Feminism. World Wars, Fascism, Communism. Existentialism, structuralism, post-modernism.

HST340.name: England and Its Culture to 1688
HST340.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST340.description: Political, social, economic, religious, and intellectual developments from the Anglo-Saxons to the revolution of 1688.

HST341.name: Modern Britain since 1688
HST341.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST341.description: Political, economic, and social survey of monarchy and party government, industrial development, rise and decline of Empire, democratization and social programs, the world wars, and cultural and literary trends.

HST342.name: Modern Eastern Europe
HST342.description: Roots of national and social conflict in the lands between Germany and Russia, from the Baltic to the Balkans, in the 19th and 20th centuries. Formation of independent states, the rise and collapse of Communism, and ethnic tensions in former Yugoslavia.

HST343.name: Russia from Peter the Great to Lenin
HST343.description: Interplay between Westernization, modernization, and imperial expansion in Imperial Russia. Revolutionary, nationalist, and peasant resistance.

HST344.name: Russia in the Twentieth Century
HST344.description: End of Imperial Russia. Soviet Union from the 1917 Revolution to 1991. Post-Soviet Russia and other successor states. Bolshevism, Stalinism, social transformation and identities.

HST347.name: Modern France
HST347.description: Politics and society from the French Revolution to the present. Impact industrialization. Changing political culture. Role of gender in society.

HST348.name: Modern Germany
HST348.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST348.description: Enlightenment, industrial and political revolutions, and national unification. Jewish emancipation and antisemitism, Catholicism and Protestantism. Nationalism and militarism. World War I, Weimar, Nazism, Holocaust. Postwar developments, reunification and aftermath.

HST351.name: Constitutional and Legal History of England since 1400
HST351.description: Developments from Henry IV's accession to the present. Constitutional principles of the Stuart monarchy and of the Glorious Revolution that underlie the modern constitution.
HST351.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HST355.name: Spain and the Muslim World
HST355.description: Spain and Portugal within and in relation to the Muslim world, especially North Africa, from the thirteenth century to approximately 1700. Muslim Iberia. Convivencia and Reconquista. Jewish communities. Expulsions and forced conversions. Moriscos and Conversos. Renegades and mercenaries. Captivity and ransom. Trade, diplomacy and warfare.

HST363.name: East Africa in the Twentieth Century
HST363.description: Background up to 1500. European invasions, colonialism, nationalism, and independence.

HST364.name: South Africa: From Shaka Zulu to Mandela
HST364.description: Social, political, and economic history. Rise of the Zulu State. European conquest and colonization. The mineral revolution. Segregation and apartheid. The liberation struggle. Democracy after 1994.

HST365.name: The Vietnam War
HST365.description: French colonial rule and the rise of Vietnamese nationalism. Communism and the Vietnamese revolution. The Cold War and American intervention. Reunification and economic renovation.

HST366.name: Modern Southeast Asia
HST366.description: Southeast Asia from 1500 to the present. Foundations of southeast Asian cultures. Religious revolutions and the rise of absolutist states. Trade and early contacts with the West. Indigenous and European empires. Forms of and responses to colonialism. Nationalist movements and independence.

HST367.name: Imperial China
HST367.description: Traditional China from the earliest period to the end of the Qing dynasty. Dynastic and state structure. Confucian, Taoist, and Buddhist traditions. Everyday lives of women and men. Social practices. Economic influences.

HST368.name: China since 1900
HST368.description: Political, social, economic, and cultural developments. The nationalist and communist revolutions. China under communism, 1940s to present.

HST369.name: Japan in the Age of the Samurai
HST369.description: Japan before 1800. Exploration of political, religious, and literary developments including Buddhism and Shinto, foreign relations and state formation, poetry and theater. Evolution of women’s roles, samurai and warfare, and early modern popular culture.

HST370.name: Modern Japan: History, Culture, and Society
HST370.description: Japan since 1800. Transformation of Japan's political structure, society, and economy from a feudalist country to a modern and militant empire, then from a war-torn and destitute nation to an economic giant with a flourishing culture in the contemporary world.

HST371.name: Women and Gender in Asia
HST371.description: Women in Asian societies, including political and religious leaders, merchants and traders, authors and artists, as well as ordinary women. Family structures, patriarchy and gendered social roles.

HST372.name: The Middle East: Islam and Empires
HST372.description: Survey of North Africa and the Arab, Persian, and Turkic lands of Southwest Asia from the rise of Islam to the early nineteenth century.

HST373.name: The Modern Middle East: From Empires to Nation States
HST373.description: Survey of the Middle East from Napoleon's invasion of Egypt (1798) to the present. Reforms and revolutions in the Safawid and Ottoman Empires. European colonialism. World War I. Rise of nation states. World War II. Islamic revolution in Iran. Modern movements. Political, cultural, social, and economic developments.

HST382.name: Modern Brazil
HST382.description: Political, economic, and social history from independence to the present. The state and the economy, social changes, and political developments.

HST383.name: The Caribbean
HST383.description: Political, economic, and social history. Sugar and slavery, nationalism, and relations with the United States.

HST384.name: Modern Mexico
HST384.description: Political, economic, and social history, including United States-Mexican relations.

HST387.name: The First World War
HST387.description: Causes of World War I, conduct of the war, and its consequences. Political, diplomatic, economic and social factors. Technological and cultural aspects.

HST388.name: World War II: Causes, Conduct and Consequences
HST388.description: Causes of World War II, conduct of the war and its consequences. Political, diplomatic, economic and social factors as well as technological and artistic aspects.

HST389.name: World War II in Asia and the Pacific
HST389.description: World War II with specific reference to Asia and the Pacific theater. Historical contexts, legacies and memories in popular culture. Relationship to modern colonialism, decolonization, nationalism and racism.

HST390.name: History of International Relations
HST390.description: Evolution of the nation state system. Its spread from Europe throughout the world and the consequences of that spread.

HST391.name: Environmental History of North America
HST391.description: Interaction of peoples of North America and their natural environments.

HST392.name: History of the Holocaust
HST392.description: Nazi persecution and genocide in Europe, 1933-1945. Jewish experience within broader context. Perpetrators, victims, bystanders, and resistors. Post-Holocaust memory, film, literature, and philosophical implications.

HST394.name: The Space Age
HST394.description: The exploration and science of aeronautics and space from the age of Galileo to the present. International relations as a driving force in technological advances. Cultural understandings and imaginings of space and space travel.

HST396.name: The City and its Discontents: Perspectives Past and Present
HST396.description: Historical transformations in modern urban social relations and their relationship to contemporary urban problems and governance.
HST396.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

HST411.name: European Jewish History
HST411.description: European Jewry since medieval era. Napoleonic emancipation, Jewish liberalism, assimilation, Zionism, anti-Semitism, and recent issues.

HST412.name: Women in Modern European History
HST412.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST412.description: Women in European society, economy, and politics since 1750, emphasizing the lives of ordinary women and the impact of industrial capitalism and the nation-state.

HST413.name: Families in Historical Perspective
HST413.description: Family forms and socio-economic change in Europe and the United States. Gender, childhood, courtship, sexual relations, marriage, divorce, childbearing, and old age in peasant, industrial, and postindustrial society. War, welfare state, and the family. The marginalized

HST420.name: History of Sexuality since the 18th Century
HST420.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST420.description: Changing gender roles, sex in the Victorian era, prostitution, pornography, birth control, emergence of homo- and heterosexuality, sex under fascism, the sexual revolution, contemporary conflicts.

HST421.name: Women and Gender in Africa
HST421.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST421.description: Gender-aware and women-centered approaches to the study of African history
HST421.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HST425.name: American and European Health Care since 1800
HST425.description: Social and cultural transformation in health care delivery since 1800, primarily in North America and western Europe. Therapeutic revolutions. Medical education and professionalization. Social and alternative medicine. Managed care.
HST425.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

HST450.name: Special Topics in African History
HST450.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST450.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting faculty.

HST451.name: Special Topics in Asian History
HST451.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST451.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting faculty

HST452.name: Special Topics in European History
HST452.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST452.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting faculty

HST453.name: Special Topics in Latin American History
HST453.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST453.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting faculty

HST454.name: Special Topics in American History
HST454.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST454.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting faculty

HST455.name: Special Topics in Modern History
HST455.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST455.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting faculty

HST456.name: Special Topics in the History of Sexuality
HST456.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting faculty.

HST475.name: History of the Book: From Manuscripts to Comics
HST475.description: History of the book from medieval manuscripts to modern forms. Publishing, illustration, censorship, manuscript and print culture.

HST480.name: Seminar in American History (W)
HST480.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST480.description: Exploration of particular topics in cultural, intellectual, or political history, seventeenth century to the present.
HST480.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST481.name: Seminar in Ancient History (W)
HST481.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST481.description: A specific problem or theme in the history of Greece and Rome.
HST481.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST482.name: Seminar in Medieval History (W)
HST482.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST482.description: A specific problem or theme in medieval social, cultural, intellectual, legal, and political history, 500-1300.
HST482.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST483.name: Seminar in Modern European History (W)
HST483.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST483.description: A specific problem or theme in European social, political, cultural, or economic history since 1300.
HST483.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST484.name: Seminar in African History (W)
HST484.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST484.description: Issues in African social, political, cultural, and environmental history.
HST484.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST485.name: Seminar in Asian History (W)
HST485.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST485.description: Intensive study of a specific problem or theme in the social, political, economic, or cultural history of Asia.
HST485.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST486.name: Seminar in Latin American History (W)
HST486.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST486.description: A specific problem or theme in the social, cultural, economic, and political history of Latin America.
HST486.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST487.name: Seminar in Comparative History (W)
HST487.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of even years
HST487.description: Analysis of themes or problems from different cultures and countries.
HST487.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST488.name: Seminar in International Relations (W)
HST488.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST488.description: A specific problem or theme in the history of international relations.
HST488.prerequisite: (HST 201 or HST 201H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HST489.name: Seminar in Digital History (W)
HST489.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST489.description: A specific problem or theme in history approached through digital research to create digital work product.
HST489.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

HST490.name: Independent Study
HST490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST490.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

HST493.name: History Internship
HST493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST493.description: Domestic and international history and history education placements with educational institutions, museums, libraries, archives, historic sites, digital history programs, public agencies, legal firms and departments, non-profit agencies, and private businesses.
HST493.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of department.

HST495.name: History Harvest
HST495.description: Identification, collection, and digitization of oral histories and historical artifacts in the local community. Family heirlooms, lived experiences of everyday people, stories passed down through generations. Emphasis on digital history techniques.

HST499H.name: Senior Honors Thesis
HST499H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST499H.description: Individual research projects, supervised by a faculty member.

HST800.name: Historiography of the United States to 1865
HST800.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST800.description: Overview of American history through the Civil War. Writings of historians on issues in social, cultural, intellectual, and/or political history.

HST801.name: Historiography of the United States Since 1865
HST801.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST801.description: Americanist historiography since the Civil War. Historical writings about issues in social, cultural, intellectual, or political history.

HST803.name: Seminar in Methodology of Historical Research
HST803.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year

HST805.name: Readings in the Historical Roots of Epidemiological Thought
HST805.description: Historical evolution of models of disease causation and population perspectives on disease.
HST805.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

HST807.name: Readings in Early American and U.S. History
HST807.description: Exploration of historical literature on a particular time period, region, or topic in Early American and U.S. History.

HST808.name: Research in Early American and U.S. History
HST808.description: Research process, methods, and sources on a particular time period, region, or topic in Early American and U.S. History.

HST810.name: Anthrohistory: Exploring the Crossroads of Anthropology and History
HST810.description: Recent trends in work between anthropology and history. Emphasis on themes of representation, methodology and epistemology.
HST810.restrictions: Open to doctoral students or approval of department.

HST812.name: History in the Digital Age
HST812.description: Historical data mining. New technologies for historical data analysis. Methods for digitizing historical materials. Web-based presentations of historical material.

HST814.name: Historiography and Social Theory
HST814.description: Social theory and historical research. Topics will vary. Potential themes include

HST816.name: Historiography of Europe since 1870
HST816.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST816.description: Readings organized around themes and genres of historical inquiry into late nineteenth and twentieth century European history.

HST822.name: Seminar in Early Modern European History
HST822.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST822.description: Political, social, and economic history of Europe from 1500-1800. Major interpretations and research methods. Topics vary.

HST823.name: Seminar in Modern European History
HST823.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST823.description: Political, social, and economic history of Europe after 1800. Major interpretations and research methods. Topics vary.

HST824.name: Seminar in Russian History
HST824.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST824.description: Political, social, and economic history of Russia. Major interpretations and research methods. Periods and topics vary.

HST829.name: African Historiography
HST829.description: Survey of important works and topics in African history

HST830.name: Seminar in African History
HST830.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST830.description: Political, social, and economic history of Africa. Major interpretations and research methods. Periods and topics vary.

HST831.name: Seminar in Latin American History
HST831.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST831.description: Political, social, and economic history of Latin America. Major interpretations and research methods. Periods and topics vary.

HST832.name: Seminar in Japanese History
HST832.description: Political, social, and economic history of Japan. Major interpretations and research methods. Periods and topics vary.

HST833.name: Seminar in Chinese History
HST833.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST833.description: Political, social, and economic history of China. Major interpretations and research methods. Periods and topics vary.

HST850.name: Seminar in Comparative History
HST850.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST850.description: Comparative themes or problems from different cultures and countries. Major interpretations and research methods.

HST855.name: Interdisciplinary Topics in Film Studies
HST855.description: Topics in film studies that engage other disciplines and fields through historical, cultural, and formal content.

HST860.name: Seminar in Women's History
HST860.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST860.description: Political, social, and economic history of women. Major interpretations and research findings. Topics vary.

HST870.name: Seminar in African-American History
HST870.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST870.description: Social, political, economic, and cultural topics emphasizing the intersection of race, class, and gender. Periods and topics vary.

HST875.name: Seminar in International Labor and Working Class History
HST875.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST875.description: History of labor, capital, and the working class in international perspective.

HST880.name: Seminar In Comparative Black History
HST880.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HST880.description: Methods and concepts that inform comparative history. The slave trade as a definitive link between Africa and the two Americas and the Caribbean, creating the black diaspora. Rise and fall of the slave trade and of disparate slave systems. Periods andtopics vary.

HST886.name: Fundamentals of Museum Studies
HST886.description: Introduction to the history of museums and current practices, standards, issues and ethics related to education, administration, visitor studies and the development, care and use of museum collections.
HST886.restrictions: Open to lifelong graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or in the Department of Anthropology or in the Department of History. Approval of department.

HST887.name: Museums and Technology
HST887.description: Theoretical and practical approaches to the way museums, zoos, gardens and other cultural sites use digital media, the web, interactive media and databases to engage the public, create virtual exhibits and web presences, and manage collections. Ways technologies are changing the definition of visitors and visitor experiences and the definitions of museums.
HST887.restrictions: Open to graduate students or lifelong graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters.

HST890.name: Independent Study
HST890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST890.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

HST897.name: Practicum in Museum Studies
HST897.semester: On Demand, On Demand, On Demand

HST898.name: Master's Research
HST898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST898.description: Directed research in support of Plan B master's degree requirements.

HST899.name: Master's Thesis Research
HST899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST899.description: Directed research in partial fulfillment of Plan A master's degree requirements.
HST899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of History.

HST900.name: Research and Pedagogy in Digital History
HST900.description: Practical and theoretical issues related to digital research, scholarship, and teaching. Identifying and using digital research tools. Creating/presenting digital scholarship. Online teaching methods. Digital methods in the classroom and for public history.

HST990.name: Independent Study
HST990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST990.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual doctoral student and a faculty member in areas supplementing the regular course offerings.
HST990.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students. Approval of department.

HST999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
HST999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HST999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of History.
